6D14B386AFF749C4AB0078032D18DBBF.description:
Chromatography: know that chromatography can be used to separate and identify the components in a mixture.
Know that there are several types of chromatography, including:
thin-layer chromatography (TLC), where a plate is coated with a solid and a solvent moves up the plate.
column chromatography (CC), where a column is packed with a solid and a solvent moves down the column.
gas chromatography (GC), where a column is packed with a solid or with a solid coated by a liquid, and a gas is passed through the column under pressure at high temperature.
Know that mass spectrometry is used to analyse the components separated by gas chromatography (GC-MS).
Understand that the separation of components depends on the balance between solubility in the moving phase and retention by the stationary phase.

44612EBD870A4AAB82B3855B082C5BE8.description:
NMR spectroscopy: appreciate that scientists have developed a range of analytical techniques which together enable the structures of new compounds to be confirmed.
Know that nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy gives information about the position of 13C or 1H atoms in a molecule.
Know that 13C NMR gives simpler spectra than 1H NMR.
Understand that 1H NMR spectra are obtained using samples dissolved in deuterated solvents or CCl4.
Know the use of the δ scale for recording chemical shift and that the δ value depends on the molecular environment of the 13C or 1H atom.
Know and explain the use of tetramethylsilane (TMS) as a standard.
Know that integrated spectra indicate the relative numbers of 1H atoms in different environments.
Be able to use integrated data from 1H NMR spectra to determine the relative numbers of equivalent protons in the molecule.
Understand and use the n+1 rule to deduce spin-spin splitting patterns of adjacent, non-equivalent protons in 1H NMR spectra, limited to doublet, triplet and quartet formation in aliphatic compounds. Be able to use 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra and chemical shift data from the Chemistry Data Booklet to suggest structures or part structures for molecules.

3B666316A4334BBD8DDB50481331762F.description:
Infrared spectroscopy: know that bonds in a molecule absorb infrared radiation at characteristic wavenumbers (frequencies).
Be able to use infrared spectra and the Chemistry Data Booklet to identify particular bonds, and therefore functional groups, and to identify impurities in a sample.
Know that “fingerprinting” allows identification of a molecule by comparison of spectra.
Understand the link between absorption of infrared radiation by bonds in CO2, methane and water vapour and global warming.

19CBFE0664684223B5A01A32EABC4F0F.description:
Revision of mass spectrometry from L6th: know that mass spectrometry can be used to determine the molecular formula of a compound.
Be able to use precise atomic masses and the precise molecular mass to determine the molecular formula of a compound.

F95A3C27DD6249DCBAE26A3309543FA6.description:
Know that the synthesis of an organic compound can involve several steps.
Explain why chemists aim to design production methods with fewer steps that have a high percentage atom economy.
Explain why chemists aim to design processes that do not require a solvent and that use non-hazardous starting materials.
Be able to use reactions covered in the course to devise a synthesis with up to four steps for an organic compound.

3968FF732D4648D599450A714EDB9E74.description: Anti-cancer drugs: know that the Pt(II) complex cisplatin is used as an anti-cancer drug. Understand that cisplatin prevents DNA replication in cancer cells by a ligand replacement reaction with DNA, in which a bond is formed between the Pt2+ ion and a nitrogen atom on guanine. Explain why cisplatin prevents DNA replication. Explain why anti-cancer drugs like cisplatin can have adverse effects. Appreciate that society needs to assess the balance between the benefits and the adverse effects of drugs, such as cisplatin.

8253011EA21A44E78F4A1B14B2B0AF8C.description:
DNA: know that DNA (deoxyribosenucleic acid) is made up of phosphate ions, 2-deoxyribose (a pentose sugar) and four bases; adenine, cytosine, guanine and thymine.  (Structures for these are given in the Chemistry Data Booklet.)
Know that a nucleotide consists of a phosphate ion bonded to 2-deoxyribose, which is in turn bonded to one of the four bases.
Know that a single strand of DNA is a polymer of nucleotides linked by covalent bonds between the phosphate group of one nucleotide and the 2-deoxyribose of another nucleotide.
Know that the linking of nucleotides results in a sugar-phosphate-sugar-phosphate polymer chain with bases attached to the sugars in the chain.
Know that DNA exists as two complementary strands arranged in the form of a double helix.
Explain how hydrogen bonding between base pairs leads to the two complementary strands of DNA.

C5C72A13673845DBBFD0CCC211DD125B.description:
Enzymes: know that enzymes are proteins.
Understand the action of proteins as catalysts, including the concept of a stereospecific active site that binds to a substrate molecule.
Understand the principle of a drug acting as an enzyme inhibitor by blocking the active site.
Know that computers can be used to help design such drugs.
Explain why a stereospecific active site can only bond to one enantiomeric form of a substrate or drug.

09808EA8F97D4B9EA818FE2E0D7CF86B.description:
Proteins: know that proteins are sequences of amino acids joined by peptide links.
Be able to draw the structure of a peptide formed from up to three amino acids.
Know that hydrolysis of peptide links produces the constituent amino acids.
Be able to draw the structures of the amino acids formed by hydrolysis of a peptide.
Know the primary, secondary (α-helix and β-pleated sheets) and tertiary structure of proteins.
Be able to identify primary, secondary and tertiary structures of proteins in diagrams.
Understand the importance of hydrogen bonding and sulfur-sulfur bonds in proteins.
Explain how the secondary and tertiary structures of proteins are maintained by hydrogen bonding and S–S bonds.

506C181BFB7B4903AC863F4D077DD6BD.description:
Amino Acids: know that amino acids have both acidic and basic properties.
Be able to draw the structures of amino acids:
as zwitterions; as ions in acid solution; as ions in alkaline solution.

B0727AD26320419FA7402BA957FFB3B6.description:
Know that polyalkenes are chemically inert and non-biodegradable.
Know that polyesters and polyamides can be broken down by hydrolysis and are biodegradable.
Be able to explain why polyesters and polyamides can be hydrolysed but polyalkenes cannot.
Appreciate the advantages and disadvantages of different methods of disposal of polymers, including recycling.

D58B9782AF3A46DEA733716B1CE2E11E.description:
Know that condensation polymers are formed by reactions between:
dicarboxylic acids and diols; dicarboxylic acids and diamines; amino acids.
Know the repeating units in polyesters, e.g., Terylene®, and polyamides, e.g., nylon 6,6 and Kevlar® and the linkages between the repeating units.
Know typical uses of these condensation polymers.
Be able to draw the repeating unit of a condensation polymer from the monomer structure(s) and from a section of the polymer chain.
Be able to draw the structure of the monomer(s) of a condensation polymer from a section of the polymer chain.
Explain the nature of the intermolecular forces between molecules of condensation polymers.

C25C5A730653427D833C95337EDEFFD8.description:
Appreciate that knowledge and understanding of the production and properties of polymers has developed over time.
Know that addition polymers are formed from alkenes and substituted alkenes.
Know the IUPAC rules for naming addition polymers.
Be able to draw the repeating unit of an addition polymer from a monomer structure and from a section of the polymer chain.
Be able to draw the structure of the monomer of an addition polymer from a section of the polymer chain.
Explain why addition polymers are unreactive.
Explain the nature of the intermolecular forces between molecules of polyalkenes.
Know some typical uses of poly(chloroethene), commonly known as PVC, and how its properties can be modified using a plasticiser.

7EC6394C6AAC43EEB2E593F3A1197727.description:
Know that amines are nucleophiles.
Understand the nucleophilic substitution reactions of ammonia and amines with halogenoalkanes to form primary, secondary and tertiary amines and quaternary ammonium salts.
Be able to outline the mechanisms for these substitution reactions.
Know that quaternary ammonium salts are used as cationic surfactants.

Link to Topic O7 – Carboxylic Acids and Derivatives:
Understand the nucleophilic addition-elimination reactions of ammonia and primary amines with acyl chlorides and acid anhydrides.
Be able to outline the nucleophilic addition-elimination mechanisms for the reactions of ammonia and primary amines with acyl chlorides.

4654F1D96B294E28B99354155AD033D8.description:
Know that amines are weak bases.
Understand and be able to explain the difference in base strength in ammonia, primary aliphatic amines and primary aromatic amines, in terms of the availability of the lone pair of electrons on the N atom.

3D479A989F8B4865A52F7ABC8FD9FD83.description:
Know that primary aliphatic amines can be prepared by the reaction of ammonia with halogenoalkanes (revision from L6th) and by the reduction of nitriles.
Know that aromatic amines are prepared by the reduction of nitro compounds and that these are used in the manufacture of dyes.

E23D42E05D614B74A1635D538AC23220.description:
Understand that electrophilic attack on the benzene ring results in substitution (limited to monosubstitution).
Know that nitration is an important step in synthesis, including the manufacture of explosives and formation of amines.
Be able to outline the electrophilic substitution mechanism of nitration, including the generation of the nitronium ion.
Know that Friedel-Crafts acylation reactions are important steps in synthesis.
Be able to outline the electrophilic substitution mechanism of acylation, using AlCl3 as a catalyst.

2CB9C15DE5E34AA4A2E2DA8A4D3D5DAF.description:
Understand the nature of the bonding in benzene, limited to its planar structure and C–C bond length intermediate between single and double.
Understand that the delocalisation of p electrons makes benzene more stable than the theoretical molecule cyclohexa-1,3,5-triene.
Be able to use thermodynamic evidence from enthalpies of hydrogenation to account for the extra stability.
Be able to explain why substitution reactions occur in preference to addition reactions.

952F4EA846B54FA2B7C6E5C520EBEC94.description:
Know the structures of acid anhydrides, acyl chlorides and amides.
Understand the nucleophilic addition-elimination reactions of water, alcohols, ammonia and primary amines with acyl chlorides and acid anhydrides.
Be able to outline the mechanisms for the nucleophilic addition-elimination reactions of acyl chlorides with water, alcohols, ammonia and primary amines.
Appreciate the industrial advantages of using ethanoic anhydride rather than ethanoyl chloride in the production of aspirin.

7D4BC4F3BC4C41E8A41BFD3FAB495350.description:
Know the structures of carboxylic acids and esters.
Understand that carboxylic acids are weak acids, but are able to liberate CO2 from carbonates.
Know that carboxylic acids react with alcohols in the presence of an acid catalyst to form esters.
Know some common uses of esters, e.g., in solvents, plasticisers, perfumes and food flavourings.
Know that esters can be hydrolysed in acid or alkaline conditions to form alcohols and carboxylic acids or salts of carboxylic acids.
Know that vegetable oils and animal fats are tri-esters of propane-1,2,3-triol (glycerol).
Understand how the alkaline hydrolysis of vegetable oils and animal fats produces soaps (salts of long-chain carboxylic acids) and glycerol.
Know that biodiesel is a mixture of methyl esters of long-chain carboxylic acids, formed by reacting vegetable oils with methanol in the presence of a catalyst.

D1A7047E5153401ABD62351054A49D02.description:
Know the use of chemical tests to distinguish between aldehydes and ketones, including Fehling’s solution and Tollens’ reagent (L6th revision). Know that aldehydes are readily oxidised to carboxylic acids.
Know that NaBH4 in aqueous solution can be used to reduce aldehydes to primary alcohols and ketones to secondary alcohols, and that these reactions are examples of nucleophilic addition.
Be able to write overall equations for these reduction reactions using [H] as the reductant.
Be able to outline the nucleophilic addition mechanism for the reduction reactions with NaBH4, with the hydride ion, H–, as the nucleophile.
Understand the nucleophilic addition reactions of carbonyl compounds with KCN, followed by dilute acid, to form hydroxynitriles.
Be able to write overall equations for these addition reactions.
Be able to outline the nucleophilic addition mechanism for the reaction with KCN followed by acid.
Appreciate the hazards of using KCN.
Understand that aldehydes and unsymmetrical ketones form mixtures of enantiomers when they react with KCN followed by dilute acid and be able to explain these observations.

Revision of optical isomerism from L6th, plus:
Know that a mixture of equal amounts of enantiomers is called a racemic mixture (racemate) and is optically inactive.
Understand how racemic mixtures are formed and why they are optically inactive.

382D503A7F074A1B9D89186D1E6C478F.description:
Metal ions in aqueous solution: explain, in terms of the charge/size ratio of the metal ion, why the acidity of [M(H2O)6]3+ is greater than that of [M(H2O)6]2+.
Know that some metal hydroxides show amphoteric character by dissolving in both acids and bases, e.g., hydroxides of Al3+.
Describe and explain the simple test-tube reactions of Fe2+, Cu2+, Fe3+ and Al3+ in aqueous solution with the bases OH–, NH3 and CO32–.

DD359718FF384B4C9E057E7CB286DBF5.description:
Catalysts: know that transition metals and their compounds can act as heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts.
Be able to explain the importance of variable oxidation state in catalysis.
Understand that a heterogeneous catalyst is in a different phases from the reactants and that reactions occur at active sites on the surface.
Know that a support medium is used to maximise the surface area and minimise the cost of a heterogeneous catalyst.
Understand that heterogeneous catalysts can become poisoned by impurities that block the active sites and this results in reduced efficiency, with a cost implication.
Explain, with the aid of equations, how V2O5 acts as a heterogeneous catalyst in the Contact process.
Know that iron is used heterogeneous catalyst in the Haber process.
Understand that a homogeneous catalyst is in the same phase as the reactants and that the reaction proceeds through an intermediate species.
Explain, with the aid of equations, how Fe2+ ions catalyse the reaction between I– and S2O82– ions.
Explain, with the aid of equations, how Mn2+ ions autocatalyse the reaction between C2O42– and MnO4– ions.

F75889EBA81B49E5A34366088A407983.description:
Variable oxidation states: know that transition metals show variable oxidation state.
Understand that the redox potential for a transition metal ion changing from one oxidation state to another is influenced by pH and by the ligand.
Know that vanadate (V) ions can be reduced by zinc in acidic solution to species in oxidation states IV, III, and II.
Know that the reduction of [Ag(NH3)2]+ in Tollens’ reagent to metallic silver is used to distinguish between aldehydes and ketones.
Know the redox titrations of Fe2+ and C2O42– with MnO4–.
Be able to perform calculations for these titrations and similar redox reactions.

5CB3C8208CB64DFEA5833C98F54DECD3.description:
Formation of coloured ions: know that transition metal ions can be identified by their colour.
Understand that colour arises when some of the wavelengths of visible light are absorbed and the remaining wavelengths are transmitted or reflected.
Know that in transition metal complexes, d electrons move from the ground state to an excited state by the absorption of visible light.
Know that the difference in energy between the ground and excited state of the electrons is given by the equation:
ΔE = hν = hc/λ (h is Planck’s constant)
Understand that changes in oxidation state, co-ordination number and ligand alter the size of ΔE and that this leads to a change in colour.
Know that the absorption of visible light is used in spectroscopy.
Understand how a simple colorimeter can be used to determine the concentration of coloured ions in solution.

83E66038104C4CA98D39390E6339E708.description:
Shapes of complex ions: know the shapes of transition metal complexes:
small ligands, e.g., H2O and NH3, commonly form octahedral complexes; larger ligands like chloride ions are commonly tetrahedral; square planar complexes are also formed; Ag+ ions form linear complexes.
Know that some complexes can exhibit isomerism:
octahedral complexes can display cis-trans isomerism (a special case of E-Z isomerism) with monodentate ligands and optical isomerism with bidentate ligands; square planar complexes can display cis-trans isomerism.
Know that cisplatin is the cis- isomer of the complex [Pt(NH3)2Cl2].
Know that the linear complex [Ag(NH3)2] + is present in Tollens’ reagent.

ADF5C68EB82A40DC895AEBB27157A06E.description:
Ligand substitution reactions: know that water and ammonia molecules and chloride ions can act as monodentate ligands.
Know that the ligands H2O and NH3 are similar in size and uncharged, and that the Cl– ion is larger than both of these uncharged ligands.
Know that exchange of H2O and NH3 occurs without change of co-ordination number, e.g., with Co2+ and Cu2+.
Know that substitution of ligands may be incomplete, e.g., the formation of [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)2]2+.
Know that the exchange of the water ligands for chloride ions can involve a change of co-ordination number, e.g., Co2+, Cu2+ and Fe3+.
Know that ligands can be bidentate (e.g., H2NCH2CH2NH2 and C2O42–) or multidentate (e.g., EDTA4–).
Understand the chelate effect as the process whereby bidentate or multidentate ligands replace monodentate ligands.
Be able to explain the chelate effect in terms of the balance between the entropy and enthalpy changes in these reactions.
Know that haem is an iron (II) complex with a multidentate ligand.
Know that oxygen forms a co-ordinate bond to the Fe2+ ion in haemoglobin, enabling oxygen to be transported in the blood.
Know that carbon monoxide is toxic because it replaces the oxygen co-ordinately bonded to haemoglobin in the blood.

804BA35BB056444D8B7F2A0DEF414261.description:
General properties of transition metals: understand that the transition metal characteristics of the elements Ti to Cu arise from an incomplete d sub-shell in atoms or ions.
Know that the characteristic properties of transitions metals include:
complex formation
formation of coloured ions
variable oxidation state
catalytic activity.
Know that a complex is a central metal atom or ion surrounded by ligands.
Know that a ligand is a molecule or ion that forms a co-ordinate bond with a (transition) metal by donating a pair of electrons.
Know that the co-ordination number is the number of co-ordinate bonds to the central metal atom or ion.

D672C9F5D5694EB0BEE411D3CCE0A71C.description:
Know the reactions of Na and Mg with water.
Know the trends in the reactions of the elements Na, Mg, Al, Si, P and S with oxygen, limited to the formation of the oxides Na2O, MgO, Al2O3, SiO2, P4O10, SO2 and SO3.
Know the trend in the melting points of the highest oxides of the elements Na to S.
Be able to explain the trend in the melting points of these oxides in terms of their structure and bonding.
Know the reactions of the oxides with water and the pH of the solutions formed.
Be able to explain the trends in the reactions of the oxides with water in terms of the type of bonding present in each oxide.
Know the structures of the acids and the anions formed when P4O10, SO2 and SO3 react with water.
Be able to write equations for the oxides of the elements with given acids and bases.

2775CD5971364540841B1651C02AFB3E.description:
Know the trends in atomic radius, first ionisation energy and melting point of the elements Mg – Ba.
Be able to explain these trends using understanding of atomic structure and bonding.
Describe the reactions of the elements Mg – Ba with water / steam.
Know the relative solubilities of the hydroxides of the elements Mg – Ba in water: Mg(OH)2 is sparingly soluble.
Know the relative solubilities of the sulfates of the elements Mg – Ba in water: BaSO4 is insoluble.
Know the use of magnesium in the extraction of titanium from TiCl4.
Know the use of Mg(OH)2 in medicine and Ca(OH)2 in agriculture.
Know the use of CaO or CaCO3 to remove SO2 from flue gases.
Know the use of BaSO4 in medicine.
Know the use of acidified BaCl2 solution to test for sulfate ions.
Be able to explain why BaCl2 solution is used in this test and why it must be acidified.

D478E482F063493A83658E50EB0A59C1.description:
Appreciate that electrochemical cells can be used as a commercial source of electrical energy.
Know the simplified electrode reactions in a lithium cell:
Positive electrode: 	Li+  +  CoO2  +  e–  →  Li+[CoO2]–; Negative electrode: 	Li  →  Li+  +  e–. Know that cells can be of three types: non-rechargeable (irreversible), rechargeable, and fuel cells.
Understand that fuel cells are used to generate an electric current and do not need to be electrically recharged.
Know the electrode reactions in an alkaline hydrogen – oxygen fuel cell.
Appreciate the benefits and risks to society associated with using these cells.
Be able to use electrode data to deduce the reactions occurring in non-rechargeable and rechargeable cells.
Be able to deduce the EMF of a cell.
Be able to explain how the electrode reactions can be used to generate an electric current.

0E7B7FF55ECB4BA089AC5CB0762C3021.description:
Know the IUPAC convention for writing half-equations for electrode reactions.
Understand the conventional representation of cells in order to be able to write and apply cell diagrams.
Know that cells are used to measure electrode potentials by reference to the standard hydrogen electrode.
Be aware of the importance of the conditions when measuring electrode potentials.  (The Nernst equation is NOT required.)
Know that standard electrode potentials, Eϴ, refer to conditions of 298K, 100kPa pressure and 1.00 mol dm-3 solutions of ions.
Know that standard electrode potentials can be listed as an electrochemical series.
Be able to calculate the EMF of a cell.
Be able to use Eϴ values to predict the direction of simple redox reactions.

2BD661B44982434A9A1A8FE40D9F95DC.description:
Appreciate that ΔH alone is not sufficient to explain feasible physical or chemical changes and that the concept of increasing disorder (entropy change, ΔS) accounts for the deficiency.
Understand that the balance between entropy and enthalpy determines the feasibility of a reaction.
Know the relationship ΔG = ΔH – TΔS (derivation not required)
Know that ΔG must be zero or negative in order for a reaction to be feasible.
Be able to calculate entropy changes from absolute entropy values.
Be able to use the relationship ΔG = ΔH – TΔS to determine how ΔG varies with temperature.
Be able to use the relationship ΔG = ΔH – TΔS to determine the temperature at which a reaction becomes feasible.

EDC6F43B672F4198862C104FCD85D051.description:
Know that a buffer solution maintains an approximately constant pH, despite dilution or the addition of small amounts of acid or base.
Know that an acidic buffer consists of a mixture of a weak acid with the salt of that weak acid.
Know that an alkaline buffer consists of a weak base and the salt of that weak base.
Be able to explain qualitatively the action of acidic and basic buffers.
Be able to calculate the pH of an acidic buffer solution.
Know some applications of buffer solutions.

984A7813E4F741AA87A46F578AF6A360.description:
Be familiar with typical pH curves for titrations of all combinations of weak and strong monoprotic acids and bases.
Be able to sketch and explain the shapes of typical pH curves.
Be able to perform calculations for these titrations based on experimental results.
Be able to use pH curves to select an appropriate indicator.

147C3EC9FFEB46938D4182A2605D261E.description:
Know that weak acids and bases dissociate only slightly in aqueous solution.
Be able to construct an expression for Ka, the dissociation constant for a weak acid.
Be able to perform calculations relating the pH of a weak acid to the concentration of the acid and the dissociation constant.
Define pKa = –log10 Ka. Be able to convert Ka into p Ka and vice versa.

D0991F247C724729971308373FE5A603.description:
Know that water is slightly dissociated into ions.
Understand how Kw is derived from the equilibrium constant for this dissociation.
Know that Kw = [H+][OH–] and that the value varies with temperature.
Be able to use Kw to calculate the pH of a strong base from its concentration.

6D8F84C5BB5A4FA28EEE219BF5CD3B3C.description:
Appreciate that the concentration of hydrogen ions in aqueous solution covers a very wide range, so a logarithmic scale is used to define pH as a measure of H+ ion concentration.
Define pH using the equation pH  = –log10 [H+]
Be able to convert the concentration of hydrogen ions into pH and vice versa.
Be able to calculate the pH of a strong acid from its concentration.

BCEF6DF4E9A24646BB149321BD46BFA8.description:
Define a Brønsted-Lowry acid as a proton donor.
Define a Brønsted-Lowry base as a proton acceptor.
Know that acid – base equilibria involve the transfer of protons.
